author: @mgamble2899

text: In 2014 I went on an Amadeus cruise with an alumni group. Most of the passengers were in alumni groups. There was also a group of doctors. It was a fairly new ship, and the accommodations and food were fine. I have no complaints. The onboard programs were educational in nature, presented mostly by professors from some of the schools represented. The shore excursions were great, maybe also geared to the educational level of the groups.
author: @steve-4045

text: You mention you‚Äôve never travelled on Tauck but warn to steer clear?  We travelled on Tauck for the Christmas Market Danube river cruise Nov 2024 and it was exceptional.  We have very high standards and only stay at 5 star resorts when traveling i.e. Four Seasons, Auberge, Rosewood.  You are obviously being compensated by another line to promote them in your other video that is a big competitor to Tauck and have lost reliability and aren‚Äôt trustworthy with this review.

text: Hi does anyone know anything about holiday max tours ?
author: @CatherineDwyer-c6x

text: Apologist for the cruise lines, obviously. If you pitch luxury, you had better deliver luxury. People aren‚Äôt as stupid as you need them to be.
author: @cmiksee1932

text:
Not surprised to find Arosa near the bottom of rankings. 
We cruised Arosa‚Äôs Christmas cruise marketed as an ‚ÄúInternational‚Äù sailing December 2022, Cologne to Strasbourg and back
80% of passengers were still German, and they received much better service than us English speakers from New Zealand, USA and England - we all had the same complaints. - Seating preferences all given to the Germans, rude, REALLY rude staff, being ignored, food was very mediocre, communication throughout was patchy, they mostly docked away from the land locations, meaning a lot of extra walking, and in the case of Strasbourg on Christmas Day, we had to walk 700 metres along the Keil side of the riverbank, figure out how to buy tickets to a train in German, then travel 1.5km by train to get into Strasbourg.
Us English speakers figured out on day 3, eat at the tables at rear of ship, where a young Russian waitress was very helpful.
The Russian lady who was 2IC in the office/shop was good, as was the Serbian lady who serviced our cabin each morning.
I could not speak well of any of the German staff, except one bartender.
They just acted like we were a nuisance for asking any slight thing.
author: @markburgess1342

text: Take these online reviews with a grain of salt. We just returned from a two-week cruise from Amsterdam to Budapest aboard the _Amadeus Imperial_ which was built in 2020 and is in excellent condition. The food was outstanding and the staff couldn't have been nicer or more helpful. The excursions were well organized and fun.
author: @bigredracingdog466

text: As an American, I would prefer a cruise that had a substantial number of people from other countries. The one river cruise I went on was almost completely American travelers, which felt like a missed opportunity.
author: @tadmarshall2739

text: Can you do a video on which river cruises have the best onboard enrichment programs?
author: @MichaelCSachs

text: Did our first river cruise on Scenic last year and absolutely loved it. Same cabins as Emerald. Truly all inclusive. Active excursions. Fantastic food & wine. We highly recommend them.  We have another cruise with Scenic booked for this fall.  Excited.
author: @billchapman8981

text: It was my understanding that Tauck caters to the European market than the US. Humm...

text:

The problem is Scylla. It‚Äôs German family owned company. Very rude, arrogant people, with no passion over what they‚Äôre doing.

text: We found our Danube cruise with Riviera Travel outstanding.  The excursions were some of the best we have ever been on.

text: Its not worth it
author: @thomas-xj1hs

text: You lost credibility when the first one you mention was Tauck and you haven‚Äôt gone on a Tauck River cruise. I stopped watching your video before it finished.
author: @terrimccullough189

text: Are you the same gentleman who put up videos on YouTube as few years back, the first entitled HOW TO AVOID TIPPING ON A CRUISE and the second HOW TO OBTAIN FREEBIES ON A CRUISE.  I haven't been on a cruise as a result as those are just the sort of people I wish to avoid.
author: @alansimpson596

text: I recently traveled on an Arosa Danube cruise as a single mum with a disabled child. It was billed as a family cruise so we were surprised to find only 3 kids onboard and thus none of the promised kids activities plus only 1 other non-German, but once we got past our shock, it was fabulous. The staff gave us a hefty discount on the excursions as they were in German, carried my child‚Äôs wheelchair on and off, gave us our own accessible dining table and much more. Easily 5 star service, quality and food. Rebooked for this year!
author: @emwoody9794

text: Thanks.
author: @DarthDaddy-cg6ro

text: Do you have any reviews on Nicko Cruises, German company. As an English speaker, I am looking to make a booking on one of their bilingual English ships for the Length of the Rhine, 8 day Basel to Amsterdam end in Cologne. Any input would be appreciated
author: @StacyEarle

text: The only river cruise I've been on was with the Tui Isla, and found it fine.  Not perfect, but then, what is?  A most enjoyable way to spend Christmas.
author: @AnnabelSmyth

text:
Caveat to begin with--we have only done one river cruise (to date), BUT we absolutely loved our Amadeus Danube cruise and would not hesitate to go back. When the captain found out that I was a former U.S. Naval Officer I was invited to the bridge for a personal tour. Perhaps other lines would have done the same, but it was quite a nice gesture. We loved our cabin and thought ALL the food was excellent.
When we do our next one it will probably be with them again because we have found with ocean going cruises that although we may like one ship over another, we definitely prefer one line after sampling multiple ones and so I doubt we will try to find a "better" one when we already like one.
author: @jonathantitus2629

text: Thanks for sharing this video. I really enjoyed it.
author: @temmietaft2552

text: Bottom line of all your reviews and viewer comments is that everyone can have a great trip , a disaster or ok one, and it covers all lines and rivers. Find one you like, don‚Äôt experiment with other lines and realize that what you like in a company might turn someone else off. Also, crew on ships are people and by definition imperfect. A great cruise this week may not be next week. Stick with YOUR winner.
author: @billwatkins8227

text: Ireland here:  Oscar Wilde is *NOT* a British literary figure.
author: @cosmic-fortytwo

text: I have taken a cruise on Amadeus when it was fully chartered by a tour company and booked directly with them.  I would have to agree with the comments.  I did not expect everyone to be apart of a tour group.  There were 5 Germans and 3 Americans (including me) that booked direct with them.  Once I realized that pretty much be solo the whole time, I had a great time.  Most of my tours I was the only american so felt like a VIP and impressed they still did the excursions with so few people.  I have looked at all the river cruises and Amadeus is the best deal for a solo traveler.  Also the cost for adding their excursions is low as well.  I definitely recommend to try them.  They also have a rewards club so easy to get aboard credit and other perks with it.  I just booked a tour again that is charting an Amadeus ship.
author: @LaurissaSaysItAll

text: Avalon is pretty good. I don‚Äôt like waiting on a hotel room for several hours after arrival in Europe.
author: @ltcajh

text: We have done two river cruises, one on Uniworld and one on Tauck. We do have three river cruises booked in 2026, all on Tauck. What we like about Tauck is their exceptional service and "all inclusive" pricing. Your Tauck tour starts at the airport where they pick you up and provide transportation to the hotel. All excursions are included... no extra costs for more exclusive excursions. Their tour directors are exceptional. Fellow travelers seem to be like minded people who have traveled a lot. I am sure that Viking would be great, and we have been on several Viking ocean cruises. I have marked off Scenic. We had a cruise cancelled during Covid, and they kept $500 saying the deposit was non-refundable. While our Uniworld river cruise was enjoyable, their ships are a little on the gaudy side. You mentioned that the Tauck ships are configured for 130 passengers compared to 150 on most other river ship which is a plus for Tauck. Tauck always seems to offer something "extra" on their tours. If you are a repeat Tauck traveler, they also offer a complimentary pre or post hotel stay for bookings more than a year in advance. I would say that the big difference between Tauck and Viking is that Tauck is more "all inclusive" while Viking is "ala cart". Based on reviews I have read and feedback from friends, I think Tauck, Viking, AmaWaterways, and Avalon would all offer a great river cruise experience for a U.S. traveler.
author: @greggibson8340

text: We like the difference from formal Cunard to non formal Viking.
author: @michaeljohnson4975

text: Oscar Wilde was not British !
author: @kerryman69

text: You should check out Viva Cruises. With good 4.5*  ship's. All incl. Drinks,  WiFi and tips.  Much cheaper than UK 's popular river cruise lines.  English is also not a problem.
author: @stephenphillipson2162

text:
Watched this with interest. We did our first ever river cruise - with Arosa, A Christmas cruise 2022. It seems the same complaints remain. - Even on their ‚Äúinternational‚Äù cruises, they did not have the social skills or attitude to treat the 40 odd non-German travellers well. We all compared notes, Brits, Americans and us kiwis. 
They gave far better treatment in table seatings, bar service, timing, everything, to the Germans. Sometimes their responses to requests, came across as very rude, and often offhand. 
The food was buffet, and very heavy. Some interpretations of non-German food, such as Paella, were inedible. It doesn‚Äôt help that many of the German guests seem to have a different interpretation of polite behaviour than non-German. 
The three best staff we found aboard - one Serbo-Croatian lady on cabin duties, and the two Russian women ‚Ä¶..
author: @markburgess1342

text: We‚Äôve traveled much of the world and done Rhine, Rhone, Bordeaux, Douro, and Danube (capitals of Eastern Europe‚Ä¶Vienna to the Black Sea) on Viking. We expect high quality service, food, and staterooms. Never had a disappointment.  Friends have done Ama and Riviera and Viking, and they gave Viking and Ama high marks, but thought Riviera was ‚Äúover-promised and under-delivered‚Äù.  Some lines seem very pretentious‚Ä¶butlers, spas, etc
author: @bobcochran2890

text: Riviera Travel and Tauck are just fine and less expensive that Viking, Ama and Uniworld.
author: @MymyMymy-b1g

text: Oscar Wilde is Irish!!!! ü§¨ü§¨ü§¨
author: @harrycobeans

text: We took a Rhine River cruise w Viking in 2008. It was terrific. The stops were all the right places. Typically, the guided tours were relatively brief and informative and provided us counseling on walk-abouts on our own. One exception - which was fine - was Heidelberg. The port was Manheim - thirty minutes by bus away from the old town. Food was very good. Crew/staff were simply there to do their jobs - not entertain. Fast forward to 2022 we booked the Rhine Cruise w Viking with Christmas Markets. The route had been altered. In 2008, Colgne was the first stop. In 2022, Dusseldorf had been added. God knows why. (The Christmas Market was late opening and our departure soon. Everything else was closed.) Cologne was later that evening much after the cathedral had closed. Essentially, the line seemed determined to conduct their normal Rhine cruise with Christmas Markets shoe-horned in where possible. The tours were longer, outside in very cold weather. We had to go on the tours to get to the markets. Again, those Christmas Markets appeared to be an afterthought. We supposed Viking was obligated to tour contracts. We'd experienced Christmas Markets in Freiberg, Kaysersberg, Colmar, Budapest and others. The Markets on this cruise deserved better. They should have been the highlight. The crew/staff were ever present in the evenings, always selling - themselves, primarily. One night, a cello/guitar duo was brought on board to entertain. These ladies were terrific. The real spoiler was the last evening briefing on how best to complete the surveys - how to best improve crew/staff chances of advancement. This cruise was not quite Carnival. But, it wasn't the quiet, under-stated Viking we loved in 2008. Obviously, I don't rate Viking particularly well these days.
author: @phskin

text: We just took a Viking cruise. Prior experience was 2 cruises on Ama Waterways. Viking sets their expectations very high in their U.S. advertising and marketing programs. We found them no better than AMA overall, and their shore excursions were not quite as good. We paid Viking for an optional winery tour that went to a very small French location that had wines I would rate no better than we can buy here in Indiana. The ship we were on was not squeaky clean either. Food was good, but again no better than Ama. However, I have to admit that at 3, our sample size of European river cruises is very small. In summary, we were pleased we did the trip, but far from overwhelmed by this Viking experience. It was a case of very high expectations that were not met.
author: @GoofballFlyer

text: Your bias against Tauck is overwhelming. Their cruises are fantastic. Makes me wonder if your reviews are based on compensation or other free trips or freebies. I hope I am wrong. Have you ever done a Tauck cruise?  Why do others rate them as the best?

text: Just come off  an Emerald Sun cruise. Totally satisfactory or excellent in all aspects except one. The dining room was so noisy that you had to raise your voice to speak across the table. Fix that, and we will be back. Leave it unchanged, you won't see us again.

text: I am currently on a Viking river cruise. They do a good job but suffer when compared to tauke. It is just a lot of small things that Tauke does better. Also, the Viking rating questionairs are misleading. You rate by expectations. So if you have high expectations and Viking meets those high expectations they only get ‚Äúmeets expectations.‚Äù

text: A group of us (4 USA women over 40) went on A-Rosa and loved it. We took one of their International cruises and had no issues. Since we were on a German river cruise, it actually felt more immersive. Food was great, premium liquor was included and when we had have a new itinerary due to low water, all was handled before we got to the ship.

text: I would really like to try TUI River Cruises, to see if I find them to be as great value as Marella. Really interesting to get your views on the river product, Gary - thanks for this!

text: Hi Gary. Great videos and very informative. I wonder if you could tell me how my wife and I would likely get on with the food provided onboard, as we are both vegetarian and have struggled somewhat when dining in Europe, especially anywhere outside of a large-ish city. Thanks in advance.

text: Great.  I am looking for a slightly less luxurious line.  I find that cruising on a river through a rather poor country on a luxurious vessel to be troubling.  I have eliminated viking for that reason.    Looking at others.  Also want to cruise the Mekong in Laos.   Wonderful to meet you.  Probably going in FEB - March 2026.
author: @ShelleyinBoston

text: It's amazing how you manage to balance your criticism with a recommendation for certain target groups, not to upset the cruise company reviewed, and at the same time deliver an interesting content for your channel subscribers.
author: @landinsongs

text: Expectations are interesting.  My husband and I did a B2B on Uniworld for our first river cruise. Great ratings but still didn't meet our expectations.  Even though I like the river cruise format, it made me nervous to spend that kind of money again.
author: @sarahsup

text: I really like your channel as it provides an abundance of information. But should I tell my friends "to stay clear" of this channel because you refuse to offer German (or any other language) dubbing? Of course not. I understand that you need catchy titles for your videos to generate clicks and hence income, but the title for this video is clearly beyond acceptable. First of all, you have not even been on some of these lines, but still feel that some frustrated souls on CruiseCritic provide 100% accurate information so you can tell others "to stay clear" of these lines? As others have rightly said, a cruise line that clearly primarily caters for a specific (non-English) language group should not be assessed by people who refuse to acknowledge that difference (or learn a foreign language). Also, a budget line cannot be ranked together with a luxury line - if the price per day is triple or more, it would be appalling to see the budget line ahead, and only that might be a reason to "stay clear" of that luxury line, but only if confirmed by own experience.
author: @TouristATSea

text: Great to know! So glad you are doing these videos. What could be worse than planning for a cruise a year in advance, flying to Europe from the states and having a less than satisfactory experience? The cost then becomes meaningless when compared to the experience. I'm not taking any chances, and my wife and I are looking forward to our first river cruise in the near future. Will definitely be referring to both of these river cruise videos when making our selection.
author: @rolandwheeler4842

text:
I remember once being told how "the worst part of any cruise is the other passengers", by that they meant that if you find you don't like being around the other people on the ship then no matter how good the cruise is in what they provide you'll have a miserable time, and while their particular example might be controversial as it involves them wanting a break from the Daily Express while relaxing by the pool deck there are countless others; noise, crowds and probably plenty else.
So I wondered if there are any tips for helping get along with passengers.
author: @edspace.

text:
English speakers traveling to German speaking countries and complaining about the language?
Sounds about right ...
author: @Dog.eatdog

text: We‚Äôve done 2 river cruises with APT. Both fabulous
author: @carolinec525

text:
Could you do a video on river cruise lines that are accessible to disabled people? I can‚Äôt find information about this subject anywhere online without going line by line myself.

I was recently on Viking from Amsterdam to Basel, and had originally booked a first floor cabin. I had to upgrade my cabin on the spot when I arrived to find out that the elevator does not go to the first floor, only from the second to the third. I was very lucky that they had any availability, as without this I would literally not have been able to get to my cabin, let alone leave for excursions or to eat meals. I will obviously be more careful in the future, but I was under the impression that Viking is more accessible than other lines, and I was definitely not left with that impression after my trip.

I have not had these problems on ocean cruises, as they generally have banks of elevators to whisk you around the ship, and it didn‚Äôt even occur to me to question the accessibility of the Viking longships.
author: @icypeanutpolo

text: Only British and North American travellers (and I say this a North American) can be so bratty, selfish, and entitled as to mark down a cruise in another country, aimed at those in that country, for using that country‚Äôs language whole just supplementing in English when needed. That‚Äôs how the rest of the world feels 99% of the time in UK and North America yet you don‚Äôt see them giving bad reviews. Outrageous.

text: I had an awful experience on Viking and found their customer service insulting. My sister traveled with me and we both found the room tiny (we‚Äôve been on other river cruises with much nicer rooms) and the food average. You have to pay for an upgraded drinks package. They were understaffed in the dining room and service was slow. The excursions, however, were very good.

text: Not sure how you can comment/judge/review if you‚Äôve never actually taken a cruise with the company.  I have been on four Tauck river cruises and all of them were exceptional. Totally all inclusive, not like some that charge extra for liquor or excursions.  Food has always been excellent with a wide range of choices. When we were off ship over lunch, Tauck gave us cash to cover our lunch and even money to buy ornaments during Christmas market tours.  I‚Äôll take smaller ships, even smaller excursion groups to exclusive locations anytime.  Take the cruise before you post reviews based on poor deduction from people‚Äôs post cruise comments.

text: My wife and I cruised an alumni group tour in April on the Amadeus Riva in Belgium and The Netherlands with AHI (Smithsonian also had a cohort.) This is a newer ship (2023), so we found the accommodations to be very nice.  The walk-in closet was wonderful. The food was good with a baker on board.  Service was excellent. The only missteps in F&B were in trying to provide Belgium waffles for breakfast with only one waffle iron and sailing through Belgium but only serving German beer.  It was cold and rainy, but the flowers were beautiful.

text: Excellent review.  Check out Nicko River Cruises which are much more reasonably priced and the clients are European based overall.
